# Visualising and Analysing Time-oriented Data

## Getting Started

### Load the R packages



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(scales, viridis, lubridate, ggthemes, gridExtra, readxl, knitr, data.table, CGPfunctions, ggHoriPlot, tidyverse)
```
:::



### Import Data



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
attacks <- read_csv("data/eventlog.csv")
```
:::



### Examining the data structure

### Data Preparation

Step 1: Deriving weekday and *hour of day* fields.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
make_hr_wkday <- function(ts, sc, tz) {
  real_times <- ymd_hms(ts, 
                        tz = tz[1], 
                        quiet = TRUE)
  dt <- data.table(source_country = sc,
                   wkday = weekdays(real_times),
                   hour = hour(real_times))
  return(dt)
  }
```
:::


Step 2: Deriving the attacks tibble data frame.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
wkday_levels <- c('Saturday', 'Friday', 
                  'Thursday', 'Wednesday', 
                  'Tuesday', 'Monday', 
                  'Sunday')

attacks <- attacks %>%
  group_by(tz) %>%
  do(make_hr_wkday(.$timestamp, 
                   .$source_country, 
                   .$tz)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(wkday = factor(
    wkday, levels = wkday_levels),
    hour  = factor(
      hour, levels = 0:23))
```
:::

## Builing the Calendar Heatmaps

Use "theme_tufte()" to remove unnecessary chart junk: No border, no axis lines, no grids. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
grouped <- attacks %>% 
  count(wkday, hour) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()

ggplot(grouped, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
coord_equal() +
scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
labs(x = NULL, 
     y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
      legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](handson_Ex07_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Building Multiple Calendar Heatmaps



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
top_countries <- attacks %>%
  count(source_country) %>%
  top_n(4, n) %>%
  pull(source_country)

grouped <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top_countries) %>%
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()

ggplot(grouped, aes(hour, wkday, fill = n)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") +
  coord_equal() +
  scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                      low = "sky blue",
                      high = "dark blue") +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL,
       title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
  theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 6)) +
  facet_wrap(~ source_country)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](handson_Ex07_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Plotting Multiple Calendar Heatmaps
Step 1: Deriving attack by country object


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
attacks_by_country <- count(
  attacks, source_country) %>%
  mutate(percent = percent(n/sum(n))) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))
```
:::


Step 2: Preparing the tidy data frame


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
top4 <- attacks_by_country$source_country[1:4]
top4_attacks <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top4) %>%
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(source_country = factor(
    source_country, levels = top4)) %>%
  na.omit()
```
:::


Step 3: Plotting Multiple Calendar Heatmaps


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(top4_attacks, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
  geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
  coord_equal() +
  scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
  facet_wrap(~source_country, ncol = 2) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks on top 4 countries by weekday and time of day") +
  theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](handson_Ex07_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




## Plotting Cycle Plot

Step 1: Data Import


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
air <- read_excel("data/arrivals_by_air.xlsx")
```
:::


Step 2: Deriving month and year fields


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
air$month <- factor(month(air$`Month-Year`), 
                    levels=1:12, 
                    labels=month.abb, 
                    ordered=TRUE) 
air$year <- year(ymd(air$`Month-Year`))
```
:::


Step 3: Extracting the target country


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Vietnam <- air %>% 
  select(`Vietnam`, 
         month, 
         year) %>%
  filter(year >= 2010)
```
:::


Step 4: Computing year average arrivals by month


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hline.data <- Vietnam %>% 
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avgvalue = mean(`Vietnam`))
```
:::


Step 5: Plotting the cycle plot


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Vietnam,
            aes(x=year, 
                y=`Vietnam`, 
                group=month), 
            colour="black") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept=avgvalue), 
             data=hline.data, 
             linetype=6, 
             colour="red", 
             size=0.5) + 
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Visitor arrivals from Vietnam by air, Jan 2010-Dec 2019") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("No. of Visitors") +
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](handson_Ex07_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




## Plotting Slopegraph
Step 1: Data Import


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rice <- read_csv("data/rice.csv")
```
:::


Step 2: Plotting the slopegraph



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rice %>% 
  mutate(Year = factor(Year)) %>%
  filter(Year %in% c(1961, 1980)) %>%
  newggslopegraph(Year, Yield, Country,
                Title = "Rice Yield of Top 11 Asian Counties",
                SubTitle = "1961-1980",
                Caption = "Prepared by: Chang Fang Yu")
```
